tools: three {@variantrule musical instrument|XUA2022ExpertClasses|musical instruments} of your choice
one {@item musical instrument|PHB} of your choice

entries: Invoking magic through music, dance, and verse, Bards are expert at inspiring others, soothing hurts, disheartening foes, and creating illusions.

Bards believe that the creators of the multiverse spoke and signed it into existence and that remnants of those Words of Creation still resound and glimmer on every plane of existence. The magic of Bards is an attempt to harness those words—which transcend any language—and direct them to create new wonders.

Almost anything can inspire a new song or tale, so Bards are fascinated by almost everything. They have a wide-ranging knowledge of many subjects and develop an aptitude to do almost anything well. Bards become masters of many things, including musical performance, the workings of magic, and the formation of jests.

Not every singer or poet in a tavern or jester in a royal court is a Bard. Harnessing the Words of Creation requires hard work and some measure of natural talent that most troubadours and jongleurs lack. It can sometimes be hard to spot the difference between these performers and Bards, though. A Bard's life is spent wandering across the land gathering lore, telling stories, and living on the gratitude of audiences, much like any other entertainer. But Bards' depth of knowledge, level of musical skill, and mastery of magic sets them apart.
Far from the bustle of cities, amid the trees of trackless forests and across wide plains, Rangers keep their unending watch.

Wanderers of the wilderness, Rangers specialize in facing monsters that threaten the world. Rangers learn to track their quarry as a predator does, moving stealthily through the wilds and hiding themselves in brush and rubble.

Thanks to their connection with nature, Rangers can also cast Spells that harness the primal powers of the wilderness. A Ranger's talents and magic are honed with deadly focus on the task of protecting the world from the ravages of monsters and tyrants.

Rogues rely on cunning, stealth, and their foes' vulnerabilities to get the upper hand in any situation. They have a knack for finding the solution to just about any problem, demonstrating a versatility that is the cornerstone of any successful adventuring party.

Rogues devote as much effort to mastering the use of a variety of skills as they do to perfecting their combat abilities, giving them broad capabilities that few other characters can match. Many Rogues focus on stealth and deception, while others refine skills that help them in a dungeon environment, such as climbing, finding and disarming traps, and opening locks.

When it comes to combat, Rogues prioritize subtle strikes over brute strength. A Rogue would rather make one precise strike than wear an opponent down with a barrage of blows. Rogues have an almost supernatural knack for avoiding danger, and a few learn magical tricks to supplement their other abilities.

Some Rogues began their careers as criminals, while others used their cunning to fight crime. Whatever a Rogue's relation to the law, no common criminal or officer of the law can match the subtle brilliance of the greatest Rogues.

classFeature.name: Bardic Inspiration
entries: You can supernaturally inspire others through words, music, or dance. This inspiration is represented by your Bardic Inspiration die, which is a {@dice d6}.

entries.name: Using Bardic Inspiration
entries: You can use your Bardic Inspiration die in the following ways:

items.name: Boost a Dice Test
items.entry: When another creature within 60 feet of you that you can see or hear fails a {@dice d20} Test, you can use your Reaction to give the creature a Bardic Inspiration die. The creature rolls that die and adds the number rolled to the {@dice d20}, potentially turning the failure into a success.

items.name: Heal
items.entry: Immediately after another creature within 60 feet of you that you can see or hear takes damage, you can use your Reaction to roll your Bardic Inspiration die and restore a number of Hit Points to the creature equal to the number rolled.

entries.name: Number of Uses
entries: A Bardic Inspiration die is expended when it's rolled. You can confer a Bardic Inspiration die a number of times equal to your Proficiency Bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ExpertClasses}.

entries.name: At Higher Levels
entries: Your Bardic Inspiration die changes when you reach certain levels in this Class, as shown in the Bardic Die column of the Bard table. The die becomes a {@dice d8} at 5th level, a {@dice d10} at 10th level, and a {@dice d12} at 15th level.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: You have learned to cast Spells through your bardic arts. See the Player's Handbook for the rules on spellcasting. The information below details how you use those rules as a Bard.

entries.name: Prepared Spells
entries: You have the following Spells prepared: {@spell Color Spray}, {@spell Disguise Self}, {@spell Prestidigitation}, and {@spell Vicious Mockery}.

Alternatively, you can prepare two 0-level Spells and two 1st-level Spells of your choice. Any Spell you prepare for this Class must be an {@variantrule Arcane Spells|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Arcane Spell}, and it must be from one of the following Schools of Magic: Divination, Enchantment, Illusion, or Transmutation.

Whenever you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ExpertClasses}, you can practice your bardic arts and replace any Spell you have prepared for this Class with another {@variantrule Arcane Spells|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Arcane Spell} of the same level, abiding by the school restriction above.

At higher levels in this Class, you can prepare more Spells, as shown on the Bard table. The numbers there determine the number of different Spells you can prepare of each level. For example, as a 3rd-level Bard, you can prepare two different 0-level Spells, four different 1st-level Spells, and two different 2nd-level Spells.

Consult the "Prepared Bard Spells" section for recommendations on which spells to prepare at higher levels. A Spell marked with a dagger (†) in that section is always prepared and can't be replaced when you prepare Spells.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Bard table shows how many Spell Slots you have at each level to cast your Bard Spells of 1st level and higher; the number of different Spells you can prepare of each level equals the number of Spell Slots you have at that level. For example, as a 5th-level Bard, you have four 1st-level Spell Slots, three 2nd-level Spell Slots, and two 3rd-level Spell Slots.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Charisma is your Spellcasting Ability for your Bard Spells.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use a {@item Musical Instrument|SCAG} as a Spellcasting Focus for the Spells you prepare for this Class.

classFeature.name: Expertise
entries: You gain {@variantrule Expertise|XUA2022ExpertClasses} in two of your Skill Proficiencies of your choice.
{@skill Performance} and {@skill Persuasion} are iconic choices for a Bard if you have Proficiency in them.

classFeature.name: Songs of Restoration
entries: You have learned how to use music, poetry, and dance to heal wounds and maladies. When you reach certain levels in this Class, you add a specific Spell to your Songs of Restoration repertoire, as shown on the Songs of Restoration Repertoire table. You always have that Spell prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of Spells you can prepare.

classFeature.name: Bard Subclass
entries: You gain the College of Lore Subclass or another Bard Subclass of your choice. The College of Lore is detailed after the Bard's Class description, and other Subclasses will appear in future Unearthed {@skill Arcana} articles.

A Subclass is a specialization that grants you special abilities at certain Bard levels. For the rest of your career, you gain each of your Subclass's features that are of your Bard level and lower. This Class's description tells you the levels when your Subclass provides features.

classFeature.name: Feat
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another {@5etools Feat|feats.html} of your choice.

classFeature.name: Jack of All Trades
entries: You can add half your Proficiency Bonus (round down) to any {@variantrule Ability Check|XUA2022ExpertClasses} you make that uses a Skill Proficiency you lack and that doesn't otherwise use your Proficiency Bonus. For example, if you make a Strength Check ({@skill Athletics}) and lack {@skill Athletics} Proficiency, you can add half your Proficiency Bonus to the check.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Bard Subclass.

classFeature.name: Font of Bardic Inspiration
entries: You now regain all your expended uses of Bardic Inspiration when you finish a Short Rest or a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ExpertClasses}.
In addition, if a creature rolls your Bardic Inspiration die and gets a 1 (after any rerolls you might have), that use of your Bardic Inspiration isn't expended.

classFeature.name: Feat
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice.

classFeature.name: Expertise
entries: You gain {@variantrule Expertise|XUA2022ExpertClasses} in two of your Skill Proficiencies of your choice.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Bard Subclass.

classFeature.name: Magical Secrets
entries: You have collected magical knowledge from a wide spectrum of disciplines. Choose a Spell List: {@variantrule Arcane Spells|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Arcane}, {@variantrule Divine Spells|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Divine}, or {@variantrule Primal Spells|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Primal}. Whenever you prepare Spells for this Class, up to two of the Spells you prepare can be from the chosen list and from any School of Magic. The prepared Spells otherwise follow the rules of your Bard Spellcasting feature.

classFeature.name: Feat
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Bard Subclass.

classFeature.name: Further Magical Secrets
entries: Your understanding of magic has grown even broader. Choose a Spell List—{@variantrule Arcane Spells|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Arcane}, {@variantrule Divine Spells|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Divine}, and {@variantrule Primal Spells|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Primal}—that you didn't choose for your Magical Secrets feature. Whenever you prepare your Bard Spells, two of the Spells you prepare can be from the chosen list and from any School of Magic. The prepared Spells otherwise follow the rules of your Bard Spellcasting feature.

classFeature.name: Feat
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice.

classFeature.name: Superior Bardic Inspiration
entries: When you roll Initiative, you regain two expended uses of your Bardic Inspiration.

classFeature.name: Feat
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice.

classFeature.name: Epic Boon
entries: You gain the {@feat Epic Boon of Luck|XUA2022ExpertClasses} Feat or another Epic Boon Feat of your choice.

classFeature.name: Expertise
entries: You gain {@variantrule Expertise|XUA2022ExpertClasses} in two of your Skill Proficiencies of your choice.
{@skill Stealth} and {@skill Survival} are iconic choices for a Ranger if you have Proficiency in them.

classFeature.name: Favored Enemy
entries: You are adept at focusing your ire on a single foe. You always have the Hunter's Mark Spell prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of Spells you can prepare. Moreover, you don't have to concentrate on the Spell once you cast it; it lasts for its full duration, until you end it as a Bonus Action, or until you are {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2022ExpertClasses}.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: You have learned to channel the magical essence of nature to cast Spells. See the Player's Handbook for the rules on spellcasting. The information below details how you use those rules as a Ranger.

entries.name: Spell Preparation
entries: You have the following Spells prepared: {@spell Cure Wounds}, {@spell Guidance|XUA2022ExpertClasses}, Hunter's Mark, and {@spell Thorn Whip}. Alternatively, you can prepare two 0-level Spells and two 1st-level Spells of your choice. Any Spell you prepare for this Class must be a {@variantrule Primal Spells|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Primal Spell}, and it can be from any School of Magic except Evocation.

Whenever you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ExpertClasses}, you can commune with nature and replace any Spell you have prepared for this Class with another {@variantrule Primal Spells|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Primal Spell} of the same level that isn't an Evocation.

At higher levels in this Class, you can prepare more Spells, as shown on the Ranger table. The numbers there determine the number of different Spells you can prepare of each level. For example, as a 3rd-level Ranger, you can prepare two different 0-level Spells and three different 1st-level Spells.

Consult the "Prepared Ranger Spells" section for recommendations on which spells to prepare at higher levels. A Spell marked with a dagger (†) in that section is always prepared and can't be replaced when you prepare Spells.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Ranger table shows how many Spell Slots you have at each level to cast your Ranger Spells of 1st level and higher; the number of different Spells you can prepare of each level equals the number of Spell Slots you have at that level. For example, as a 5th-level Ranger, you have four 1st-level Spell Slots and two 2nd-level Spell Slots.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Wisdom is your Spellcasting Ability for your Ranger Spells.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use a Druidic Focus as a Spellcasting Focus for the Spells you prepare for this Class.

classFeature.name: Fighting Style
entries: You have honed your martial prowess. You gain one of the following Fighting Style Feats of your choice: Archery, Defense, or Two-Weapon Fighting.
Whenever you gain a Feat at later levels, Fighting Style Feats are among your options, even though you aren't a member of the Warrior Group.

classFeature.name: Ranger Subclass
entries: You gain the Hunter Subclass or another Ranger Subclass of your choice. The Hunter is detailed after the Ranger's Class description, and other Subclasses will appear in future Unearthed Arcana articles.

A Subclass is a specialization that grants you special abilities at certain Ranger levels. For the rest of your career, you gain each of your Subclass's features that are of your Ranger level and lower. This Class's description tells you the levels when your Subclass provides features.

classFeature.name: Feat
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice.

classFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: You can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the {@action Attack|XUA2022ExpertClasses} on your turn.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Ranger Subclass.

classFeature.name: Roving
entries: Your Speed increases by 10 feet while you aren't wearing Heavy Armor.
You also have a {@variantrule Climb Speed|XUA2022ExpertClasses} and a {@variantrule Swim Speed|XUA2022ExpertClasses} equal to your Speed.

classFeature.name: Feat
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice.

classFeature.name: Expertise
entries: You gain {@variantrule Expertise|XUA2022ExpertClasses} in two of your Skill Proficiencies of your choice.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Ranger Subclass.

classFeature.name: Tireless
entries: Primal forces now help fuel you on your journeys, granting you the following benefits:

entries.name: Temporary Hit Points
entries: Whenever you finish a Short Rest or a Long Rest, you can give yourself a number of Temporary Hit Points equal to {@dice 1d8} plus your Proficiency Bonus.

entries.name: Decrease Exhaustion
entries: If you are {@condition Exhausted|XUA2022ExpertClasses} when you finish a Short Rest, your level of {@condition exhaustion} decreases by 1.

classFeature.name: Feat
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice.

classFeature.name: Nature's Veil
entries: You invoke spirits of nature to magically hide yourself from view. As a Bonus Action, you can expend a Spell Slot and become {@condition Invisible|XUA2022ExpertClasses} until the end of your next turn.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Ranger Subclass.

classFeature.name: Feral Senses
entries: Your connection to the forces of nature grants you {@feat Blindsight|XUA2022ExpertClasses} with a range of 30 feet.

classFeature.name: Feat
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice.

classFeature.name: Foe Slayer
entries: Your Hunter's Mark now deals an extra {@damage 1d10} damage to its target, rather than an extra {@dice 1d6}.

classFeature.name: Feat
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice.

classFeature.name: Epic Boon
entries: You gain the Epic Boon of Fortitude Feat or another Epic Boon Feat of your choice.

classFeature.name: Expertise
entries: You gain {@variantrule Expertise|XUA2022ExpertClasses} in two of your Skill Proficiencies of your choice.
{@skill Sleight of Hand} and {@skill Stealth} are iconic choices for a Rogue if you have Proficiency in them.

classFeature.name: Sneak Attack
entries: You know how to turn a subtle attack into a deadly one. Once on each of your turns when you take the {@action Attack|XUA2022ExpertClasses} Action, you can deal extra damage to one creature you hit with an {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ExpertClasses} if you're attacking with a Finesse Weapon or a Ranged Weapon and if at least one of the following requirements is met:

items.name: Advantage
entries: You have Advantage on the {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ExpertClasses}.

items.name: Ally Adjacent to Target
entries: At least one of your allies is within 5 feet of the target, the ally isn't {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2022ExpertClasses}, and you don't have Disadvantage on the {@action Attack|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Attack Roll.}

To determine the extra damage, roll a number of d6s equal to half your Rogue level (round up), and add the dice together (the Rogue table shows the number of Sneak Attack dice you get at each Rogue level). The extra damage's type is the same as the weapon's Damage Type.

classFeature.name: Thieves' Cant
entries: You picked up various languages in the communities where you plied your roguish talents. You know Thieves' Cant and one other language of your choice, which you choose from the Standard Languages and Rare Languages tables.

classFeature.name: Cunning Action
entries: Your quick thinking and agility allow you to move and act quickly. On your turn, you can take one of the following Actions as a Bonus Action: {@action Dash|XUA2022ExpertClasses}, {@action Disengage}, or {@action Hide|XUA2022ExpertClasses}.

classFeature.name: Rogue Subclass
entries: You gain the Thief Subclass or another Rogue Subclass of your choice. The Thief is detailed after the Rogue's Class description, and other Subclasses will appear in future Unearthed {@skill Arcana} articles.

A Subclass is a specialization that grants you special abilities at certain Rogue levels. For the rest of your career, you gain each of your Subclass's features that are of your Rogue level and lower. This Class's description tells you the levels when your Subclass provides features.

classFeature.name: Feat
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice.

classFeature.name: Uncanny Dodge
entries: When an attacker that you can see hits you with an {@action Attack|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Attack Roll}, you can use your Reaction to halve the attack's damage against you (round down).

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Rogue Subclass.

classFeature.name: Expertise
entries: You gain {@variantrule Expertise|XUA2022ExpertClasses} in two of your Skill Proficiencies of your choice.

classFeature.name: Feat
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice.

classFeature.name: Evasion
entries: You can nimbly dodge out of the way of certain dangers. When you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity Saving Throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the Saving Throw and only half damage if you fail. You can't use this feature if you're {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2022ExpertClasses}.

classFeature.name: Feat
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Rogue Subclass.

classFeature.name: Reliable Talent
entries: You have refined your talents until they approach perfection. Whenever you make an {@variantrule Ability Check|XUA2022ExpertClasses} that uses one of your Skill or Tool Proficiencies, you can treat a {@dice d20} roll of 9 or lower as a 10.

classFeature.name: Feat
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice.

classFeature.name: Subtle Strikes
entries: When you attack, you know how to exploit a target's distraction. You have Advantage on any {@action Attack|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Attack Roll} that targets a creature that is within 5 feet of at least one of your allies who isn't {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2022ExpertClasses}.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Rogue Subclass.

classFeature.name: Slippery Mind
entries: Your cunning mind is exceptionally difficult to control. You gain Proficiency in Wisdom and Charisma Saving Throws.

classFeature.name: Feat
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice.

classFeature.name: Elusive
entries: You are so evasive that attackers rarely gain the upper hand against you. No {@action Attack|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Attack Roll} has Advantage against you while you aren't {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2022ExpertClasses}.

classFeature.name: Stroke of Luck
entries: You have an uncanny knack for succeeding when you need to. If you fail a {@variantrule D20 Tests|XUA2022ExpertClasses|d20 Test}, you can turn the roll into a 20. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a Short Rest or a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ExpertClasses}.

classFeature.name: Feat
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice.

classFeature.name: Epic Boon
entries: You gain the Epic Boon of Undetectability Feat or another Epic Boon Feat of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: College of Lore
entries: Bards of the College of Lore know something about most things, collecting bits of knowledge from sources as diverse as scholarly tomes and peasant tales. Whether singing folk ballads in taverns or performing elaborate compositions in royal courts, these Bards use their gifts to hold audiences spellbound.

The college's members gather in libraries and sometimes in actual colleges, complete with classrooms and dormitories, to share their lore with one another. They also meet at festivals or affairs of state, where they can expose corruption, unravel lies, and poke fun at selfimportant figures of authority.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiencies
entries: You gain three Skill Proficiencies: {@skill Arcana}, {@skill History}, and {@skill Nature}. If you already have one of these Proficiencies, choose a Skill Proficiency you lack, and gain that Proficiency

subclassFeature.name: Cutting Words
entries: You learn how to use your wit to supernaturally distract, confuse, and otherwise sap the confidence and competence of others. When a creature that you can see within 60 feet of yourself succeeds on an {@variantrule Ability Check|XUA2022ExpertClasses} or an {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ExpertClasses}, you can use your Reaction to expend one of your uses of Bardic Inspiration, rolling a Bardic Inspiration die and subtracting the number rolled from the creature's roll, potentially turning it into a failure.

subclassFeature.name: Cunning Inspiration
entries: Through your studies and your cunning, you've learned to inspire others exceptionally well. When any creature rolls your Bardic Inspiration die, that creature can roll the die twice and use the higher of the two rolls.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Cutting Words
entries: Whenever you use your Cutting Words feature on a creature, you can deal Psychic Damage to that creature equal to the number rolled on the Bardic Inspiration die plus your Charisma modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Peerless Skill
entries: When you make an {@variantrule Ability Check|XUA2022ExpertClasses} and fail, you can expend one use of Bardic Inspiration, roll the Bardic Inspiration die, and add the number rolled to the {@variantrule Ability Check|XUA2022ExpertClasses}, potentially turning it into a success. If the check still fails, the Bardic Inspiration isn't expended.

subclassFeature.name: Hunter
entries: You stalk prey in the wilds and elsewhere, using your abilities as a Hunter to protect nature and people everywhere from forces that would destroy them.

subclassFeature.name: Hunter's Prey
entries: Your tenacity can wear down even the most resilient foes. When you hit a creature with a Weapon or an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XUA2022ExpertClasses} as part of the {@action Attack|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Attack Action} on your turn, the Weapon or {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XUA2022ExpertClasses} deals an extra {@damage 1d8} damage to the target if it's missing any of its Hit Points. You can deal this extra damage only once per turn.

subclassFeature.name: Hunter's Lore
entries: You can call on the forces of nature to reveal certain strengths and weaknesses of your prey. While a creature is marked by your Hunter's Mark, you know whether that creature has any Immunities, Resistances, and Vulnerabilities, and if the creature has any, you know what they are.

subclassFeature.name: Multiattack
entries: You now always have Conjure Barrage prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of Spells you can prepare.
You can also cast the Spell with 1st- and 2nd level Spell Slots. When you do so, the Spell's damage is reduced by {@dice 1d8} for each slot level below 3rd.

subclassFeature.name: Superior Hunter's Defense
entries: When you are hit by an {@action Attack|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Attack Roll}, you can use your Reaction to halve the attack's damage against yourself, and you can redirect the other half of the damage to one creature (other than the attacker) that you can see within 5 feet of yourself.

subclassFeature.name: Fast Hands
entries: You have additional options for the Bonus Action of your Cunning Action, with which you can do the following:

items.name: Search
entries: Take the {@action Search Action|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Search Action}.

items.name: Sleight of Hand
entries: Make a Dexterity Check ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) to pick a lock or disarm a trap with Thieves' Tools or to pick a pocket

subclassFeature.name: Second-Story Work
entries: You have trained to reach especially hard-toreach places, granting you these benefits:

items.name: Climb Speed
entries: You gain a {@variantrule Climb Speed|XUA2022ExpertClasses} equal to your Speed.

items.name: Jump Distance
entries: When you take the {@action Jump|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Jump Action}, you can make a Dexterity Check, instead of a Strength Check.

subclassFeature.name: Thief
entries: You have honed your larcenous arts. Burglars, bandits, cutpurses, and other criminals typically adopt this Subclass, but so do Rogues who prefer to think of themselves as treasure seekers, explorers, delvers, and investigators.
In addition to improving your agility and stealthiness, you gain abilities useful for delving into ruins and getting maximum benefit from the magic items you find there.

subclassFeature.name: Supreme Sneak
entries: You have Advantage on every Dexterity Check ({@skill Stealth}) you make, provided you aren't wearing Medium or Heavy Armor.

subclassFeature.name: Use Magic Device
entries: In your treasure hunting, you have learned how to maximize use of magic items, granting you the following benefits:

items.name: Attunement
entries: You can attune to up to four magic items at once.

items.name: Charges
entries: Whenever you use a magic item property that expends charges, roll a {@dice d6}. On a roll of 6, you use the property without expending the charges.

items.name: Scrolls
entries: You can use any {@item Spell Scroll} that bears a cantrip or a 1st-level Spell. You can also try to use any {@item Spell Scroll} that contains a higher-level Spell, but you must first succeed on an Intelligence Check (Arcana) with a DC equal to 10 + the Spell's level. On a successful check, you cast the Spell from the scroll, and you use Intelligence as your Spellcasting Ability for this casting. On a failed check, the scroll disintegrates.

subclassFeature.name: Thief's Reflexes
entries: You can now take a second Bonus Action on your turn, provided it is the Bonus Action from Cunning Action. You can use this feature on a number of turns equal to your Proficiency Bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ExpertClasses}.

feat.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You increase one Ability Score of your choice by 2, or you increase two Ability Scores of your choice by 1. You can't increase an Ability Score above 20.

feat.name: Actor
entries: Skilled at mimicry and dramatics, you gain the following benefits:

items.name: Impersonation
entries: While you're disguised as a fictional person or a real person other than yourself, you have Advantage on Charisma Checks ({@skill Performance}) to convince others that you are that person.

items.name: Mimicry
entries: You can mimic the sounds of other creatures, including speech. To mimic a sound or a way of speaking, you must listen to it for at least 1 minute. Any time thereafter, you can make a {@dc 15} Charisma Check ({@skill Performance}) to perform the mimicry; on a success, you perform it convincingly for up to 1 hour.

feat.name: Athlete
entries: You have undergone extensive physical training to gain the following benefits:

items.name: Climb Speed
items.entry: You gain a {@variantrule Climb Speed|XUA2022ExpertClasses} equal to your Speed.

items.name: Hop Up
items.entry: When you are Prone, you can right yourself with only 5 feet of movement. Jumping. You have Advantage on any {@variantrule Ability Check|XUA2022ExpertClasses} you make for the {@action Jump|XUA2022ExpertClasses} Action.

feat.name: Charger
entries: You have trained to charge headlong into battle, gaining the following benefits:

items.name: Improved Dash
items.entry: When you take the {@action Dash|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Dash Action}, your Speed increases by 10 feet for that Action.

items.name: Charge Attack
items.entry: If you move at least 10 feet in a straight line immediately before hitting with an attack as part of the {@action Attack|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Attack Action} on your turn, choose one of the following effects: gain a{@dice  + 1d8} bonus to the attack's damage roll, or push the target up to 10 feet, provided the target you want to push is no more than one Size larger than you. You can use this benefit only once on each of your turns.

feat.name: Crossbow Expert
entries: Thanks to extensive practice with crossbows, you gain the following benefits:

items.name: Ignore Loading
items.entry: You ignore the Loading property of crossbows.

items.name: Firing in Melee
items.entry: Being within 5 feet of an enemy doesn't impose Disadvantage on your {@variantrule Attack Rolls|XUA2022ExpertClasses} with crossbows.

items.name: Dual Wielding
items.entry: When you make the extra attack of the {@variantrule Light|XUA2022ExpertClasses} weapon property, you can add your Ability Modifier to the damage of the extra attack if that attack is with a crossbow that has the {@variantrule Light|XUA2022ExpertClasses} property.

feat.name: Defensive Duelist
entries: You've learned to deftly parry attacks, granting you the following benefits:

items.name: Parry
items.entry: If you are holding a Finesse Weapon and another creature hits you with a Melee Attack, you can use your Reaction to add your Proficiency Bonus to your Armor Class for that attack, potentially causing the attack to miss you.

feat.name: Dual Wielder
entries: You master fighting with two weapons, gaining the following benefits:

items.name: Enhanced Dual Wielding
items.entry: When you are holding a Weapon with the Light property in one hand, you can treat a non-Light Weapon in your other hand as if it had the Light property, provided that Weapon lacks the Two-Handed property.

items.name: Quick Draw
items.entry: You can draw or stow two Weapons that lack the Two-Handed property when you would normally be able to draw or stow only one.

feat.name: Durable
entries: Hardy and resilient, you gain the following benefits:

items.name: Defy Death
items.entry: You have Advantage on Death Saving Throws.

items.name: Speedy Recovery
items.entry: As a Bonus Action, you can expend one of your Hit Dice, roll the die, and regain a number of Hit Points equal to the roll.

feat.name: Elemental Adept
feat.repeatableNote: Yes, but you must choose a different Damage Type each time for Energy Mastery
entries: In your spellcasting, you can harness a particular form of energy with deadly mastery, granting you the following benefits:

items.name: Energy Mastery
items.entry: Choose one of the following Damage Types: Acid, Cold, Fire, Lightning, or Thunder. Spells you cast ignore Resistance to damage of the chosen type. In addition, when you roll damage for a Spell you cast that deals damage of that type, you can treat any 1 on a damage die as a 2.

feat.name: Epic Boon of Combat Prowess
entries: When you miss with a Melee Attack, you can hit instead. Once you use this benefit, you can't use it again until you roll Initiative.

feat.name: Epic Boon of Dimensional Travel
entries: You can cast the {@spell Misty Step} Spell without expending a Spell Slot. Once you use this benefit, you can't use it again until you roll Initiative or finish a Short Rest or a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ExpertClasses}.

feat.name: Epic Boon of Energy Resistance
entries: You gain Resistance to one of the following Damage Types of your choice: Acid, Cold, Fire, Lightning, Necrotic, Poison, Psychic, Radiant, or Thunder.
Whenever you finish a Short Rest or a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ExpertClasses}, you can meditate and change that Damage Type choice.

feat.name: Epic Boon of Fortitude
entries: Your Hit Point Maximum increases by 40
In addition, whenever you regain Hit Points, you regain additional Hit Points equal to your Constitution Modifier. You can regain these additional Hit Points no more than once per round.

feat.name: Epic Boon of Irresistible Offense
entries: The damage you deal always ignores Resistance.

feat.name: Epic Boon of Luck
entries: Immediately after you roll a {@dice d20} for a {@variantrule d20 Test|XUA2022ExpertClasses}, you can roll a {@dice d10} and add the number rolled to the test. Once you use this benefit, you can't use it again until you roll Initiative or finish a Short Rest or a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ExpertClasses}.

feat.name: Epic Boon of Peerless Aim
entries: If you make a Ranged Attack against a target in range and miss, you can cause the attack to hit instead. Once you use this benefit, you can't use it again until you roll Initiative.

feat.name: Epic Boon of Recovery
entries: You can use a Bonus Action to regain a number of Hit Points equal to half your Hit Point Maximum. Once you use this benefit, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ExpertClasses}.
In addition, you succeed on every Death Saving Throw that isn't a roll of 1.

feat.name: Epic Boon of Skill Proficiency
entries: You gain Proficiency in all Skills.

feat.name: Epic Boon of Speed
entries: Your Speed increases by 30 feet.

feat.name: Epic Boon of the Night Spirit
entries: While within Dim Light or Darkness, you can become {@condition Invisible|XUA2022ExpertClasses} as an Action. You remain {@condition Invisible|XUA2022ExpertClasses} until immediately after you take an Action or a Reaction.

feat.name: Epic Boon of the Unfettered
entries: As a Bonus Action, you can take the {@action Disengage} Action, which also ends the {@condition Grappled|XUA2022ExpertClasses} and the Restrained Conditions on you.

feat.name: Epic Boon of Undetectability
entries: You can't be seen or heard by any means—magical or nonmagical—while you are {@condition Hidden|XUA2022ExpertClasses}.

feat.name: Fighting Style: Archery
entries: You gain a +2 bonus to {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ExpertClasses} you make with Ranged Weapons.

feat.name: Fighting Style: Defense
entries: While you are wearing armor, you gain a +1 bonus to Armor Class.

feat.name: Fighting Style: Dueling
entries: When you are wielding a Melee Weapon in one hand and no other Weapons, you gain a +2 bonus to damage rolls with that Melee Weapon.

feat.name: Fighting Style: Great Weapon Fighting
entries: When you roll a 1 or 2 on a damage die for an attack you make with a Melee Weapon that you are wielding with two hands, you can reroll the die, and you must use the new roll. The Weapon must have the Two-Handed or Versatile property to gain this benefit.

feat.name: Fighting Style: Protection
entries: Immediately after a creature you can see makes an {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ExpertClasses} and hits a target other than you that is within 5 feet of you, you can use your Reaction to interpose your Shield and impose a −2 penalty on the {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ExpertClasses}, potentially turning it into a miss. You must be wielding a Shield to use this Reaction.

feat.name: Fighting Style: Two-Weapon Fighting
entries: When you make the extra attack of the {@variantrule Light|XUA2022ExpertClasses} weapon property, you can add your Ability Modifier to the damage of the extra attack.

feat.name: Grappler
entries: You're an accomplished wrestler, granting you the following benefits:

items.name: Attack Advantage
items.entry: You have Advantage on {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Attack Rolls} against a creature {@condition Grappled|XUA2022ExpertClasses} by you.

items.name: Fast Wrestler
items.entry: You aren't {@variantrule Slowed|XUA2022ExpertClasses} when you move a creature {@condition Grappled|XUA2022ExpertClasses} by you, provided the creature is your Size or smaller.

items.name: Punch and Grab
items.entry: When you hit a creature with an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XUA2022ExpertClasses} as part of the {@action Attack|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Attack Action} on your turn, you can deal damage to the target and also grapple it. You can use this benefit only once per turn.

feat.name: Great Weapon Master
entries: You've learned to use the weight of a weapon to your advantage, letting its momentum empower your strikes. You gain the following benefits:

items.name: Cleave
items.entry: Immediately after you score a Critical Hit with a Melee Weapon or reduce a creature to 0 Hit Points with one, you can make one attack with the same weapon as a Bonus Action.

items.name: Heavy Weapon Mastery
items.entry: When you hit a creature with a Heavy Weapon as part of the {@action Attack|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Attack Action} on your turn, you can cause the weapon to deal extra damage to the target. The extra damage equals your Proficiency Bonus, and you can deal it only once per turn.

feat.name: Heavily Armored
entries: You have trained to use Heavy Armor effectively, gaining the following benefits:

items.name: Armor Training
items.entry: You gain Heavy {@variantrule Armor Training|XUA2022ExpertClasses}.

feat.name: Heavy Armor Master
entries: You can use your Heavy Armor to deflect strikes, granting you the following benefits:

items.name: Damage Reduction
items.entry: When you're hit by an attack while you're wearing Heavy Armor, any Bludgeoning, Piercing, or Slashing Damage dealt to you by that attack is reduced by an amount equal to your Proficiency Bonus

feat.name: Inspiring Leader
entries: You are adept at encouraging others, granting you the following benefits:

items.name: Encouraging Performance
items.entry: At the end of a Short Rest or a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ExpertClasses}, you can give an inspiring performance: a speech, a song, or a dance. When you do so, choose up to six friendly creatures (which can include yourself) within 30 feet of you who witness the performance. The chosen creatures each gain Temporary Hit Points equal to {@dice 2d4} + your Proficiency Bonus.

feat.name: Keen Mind
entries: You have trained to rapidly recall or discover vital details, granting you the following benefits:

items.name: Lore Knowledge
items.entry: Choose one of the following Skills: {@skill Arcana}, {@skill History}, {@skill Investigation}, {@skill Nature}, or {@skill Religion}. If you lack Proficiency in the chosen Skill, you gain Proficiency in it, and if you have Proficiency in it, you gain {@variantrule Expertise|XUA2022ExpertClasses} in it.

items.name: Quick Study
items.entry: You can take the {@action Study|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Study Action} as a Bonus Action.

feat.name: Lightly Armored
entries: You gain the following {@variantrule Armor Training|XUA2022ExpertClasses}: Light Armor, Medium Armor, and Shield.

feat.name: Mage Slayer
entries: You have practiced techniques useful in battling magic-users, gaining the following benefits:

items.name: Concentration Breaker
items.entry: When you damage a creature that is concentrating, it has Disadvantage on the Saving Throw it makes to maintain Concentration.

items.name: Guarded Mind
items.entry: If you fail an Intelligence, a Wisdom, or a Charisma Saving Throw, you can cause yourself to succeed instead. Once you use this benefit, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ExpertClasses}.

feat.name: Medium Armor Master
entries: You have practiced moving in medium armor to gain the following benefits:

items.name: Dexterous Wearer
items.entry: While you are wearing Medium Armor, you can add 3, rather than 2, to your AC if you have a Dexterity score of 16 or higher.

feat.name: Mounted Combatant
entries: You have developed a bond with your mounts, granting you the following benefits:

items.name: Mount Handler
items.entry: You have Advantage on Wisdom Checks ({@skill Animal Handling}) made to handle or train horses and other Beasts employed as mounts

items.name: Mounted Strike
items.entry: While mounted, you have Advantage on {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Attack Rolls} against any creature that is within 5 feet of your mount and at least one Size smaller than it.

items.name: Leap Aside
items.entry: If your mount is subjected to an effect that allows it to make a Dexterity Saving Throw to take only half damage, it instead takes no damage if it succeeds on the Saving Throw, and only half damage if it fails. For your mount to gain this benefit, you must be riding it, and neither of you can be {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2022ExpertClasses}.

items.name: Veer
items.entry: While mounted, you can use your Reaction to force an attack that hits your mount to hit you instead.

feat.name: Observant
entries: Quick to notice details around you, you gain the following benefits:

items.name: Keen Observer
items.entry: Choose one of the following Skills: {@skill Insight}, {@skill Investigation}, or {@skill Perception}. If you lack Proficiency with the chosen Skill, you gain Proficiency in it, and if you have Proficiency in it, you gain {@variantrule Expertise|XUA2022ExpertClasses} in it.

items.name: Quick Search
items.entry: You can take the {@action Search|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Search Action} as a Bonus Action.

feat.name: Polearm Master
entries: You have trained extensively with pole weapons that have Reach, granting you the following benefits:

items.name: Pole Strike
items.entry: Immediately after you take the {@action Attack|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Attack Action} and attack with a Weapon that has the Heavy and Reach properties, you can use a Bonus Action to make a Melee Attack with the opposite end of the Weapon. The weapon's damage die for this attack is a {@dice d4}, and it deals Bludgeoning Damage.

items.name: Reactive Strike
items.entry: While you are holding a Weapon that has the Heavy and Reach properties, you can use your Reaction to make one Melee Attack against a creature that enters the Reach you have with that Weapon.

feat.name: Resilient

choose.entry: Choose one ability in which you lack Saving Throw Proficiency. Increase the chosen Ability Score by 1, to a maximum of 20.

entries: You have developed the resilience to better withstand certain dangers, granting you the following benefits:

items.name: Saving Throw Proficiency
items.entry: You gain Saving Throw Proficiency with the chosen ability.

feat.name: Ritual Caster
entries: You have studied ritual magic, granting you the following benefits:

items.name: Ritual Spells
items.entry: Choose two 1st-level Spells that have the Ritual tag from the {@variantrule Arcane Spells|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Arcane}, {@variantrule Divine Spells|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Divine}, and {@variantrule Primal Spells|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Primal} {@variantrule Spell Lists|XUA2022ExpertClasses}. You always have those two Spells prepared, and you can cast them with any Spell Slots you have. The Spells' Spellcasting Ability is the ability increased by this Feat.

items.name: Quick Ritual
items.entry: With this benefit, you can cast a Ritual Spell that you have prepared using its regular casting time, rather than the extended time for a Ritual. Doing so doesn't require a Spell Slot. Once you cast the Spell in this way, you can't use this benefit again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ExpertClasses}.

feat.name: Sentinel
entries: You have mastered techniques to take advantage of every drop in any enemy's guard, gaining the following benefits:

items.name: Guardian
items.entry: Immediately after a creature within 5 feet of you takes the {@action Disengage} Action or hits a target other than you with an attack, you can make an Opportunity Attack against that creature.

items.name: Halt
items.entry: When you hit a creature with an Opportunity Attack, the creature's Speed becomes 0 for the rest of the turn.

feat.name: Sharpshooter
entries: You can make shots that others find impossible, granting you the following benefits:

items.name: Bypass Cover
items.entry: Your Ranged Attacks with Weapons ignore Half Cover and Three-Quarters Cover.

items.name: Firing in Melee
items.entry: Being within 5 feet of an enemy doesn't impose Disadvantage on your ranged {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Attack Rolls} with Weapons.

items.name: Long Shots
items.entry: Attacking at Long Range doesn't impose Disadvantage on your ranged {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Attack Rolls} with Weapons.

feat.name: Shield Master
entries: You've trained to use shields not just for protection, but also for offense, granting you the following benefits:

items.name: Shield Bash
items.entry: If you attack a creature within 5 feet of you as part of the {@action Attack|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Attack Action} and hit with a Melee Weapon, you can immediately bash the target with your Shield if it's equipped, forcing the target to make a Strength Saving Throw against a DC equal to 8 + your Strength modifier + your Proficiency Bonus. On a failed save, you knock the target Prone or push it 5 feet away. You can use this benefit only once on each of your turns.

items.name: Interpose Shield
items.entry: If you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity Saving Throw to take only half damage, you can use your Reaction to take no damage if you succeed on the Saving Throw and are wielding a Shield, interposing your shield between yourself and the source of the effect.

feat.name: Skulker
entries: You are expert at slinking through shadows, granting you the following benefits:

items.name: Blindsight
items.entry: You have {@variantrule Blindsight|XUA2022ExpertClasses} with a range of 10 feet.

items.name: Fog of War
items.entry: Exploiting the distractions of battle, you have Advantage on any Dexterity Check ({@skill Stealth}) you make as part of the {@action Hide|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Hide Action} during combat.

items.name: Sniper
items.entry: If you make an {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ExpertClasses} while {@condition Hidden|XUA2022ExpertClasses} and the roll misses, making the {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ExpertClasses} doesn't end the {@condition Hidden|XUA2022ExpertClasses} Condition on you.

feat.name: Speedster
entries: You possess exceptional speed and stamina, granting you the following benefits:

items.name: Speed Increase
items.entry: Your Speed increases by 10 feet while you aren't wearing Heavy Armor.

items.name: Dash Over Difficult Terrain
items.entry: When you take the {@action Dash|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Dash Action} on your turn, {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XUA2022ExpertClasses} doesn't cost you extra movement for the rest of that turn.

feat.name: Spell Sniper
entries: You have learned techniques to enhance your attacks with certain kinds of spells, gaining the following benefits:

items.name: Bypass Cover
items.entry: Your {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Attack Rolls} for Spells ignore Half Cover and Three-Quarters Cover

items.name: Casting in Melee
items.entry: Being within 5 feet of an enemy doesn't impose Disadvantage on your {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Attack Rolls} with Spells.

items.name: Increased Range
items.entry: When you cast a Spell that has a range of at least 10 feet and that requires you to make an {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ExpertClasses}, you can increase the Spell's range by 60 feet.

feat.name: War Caster
entries: You have practiced casting spells in the midst of combat, granting you the following benefits:

items.name: Concentration
items.entry: You have Advantage on Constitution Saving Throws that you make to maintain your Concentration.

items.name: Reactive Spell
items.entry: When a creature provokes an Opportunity Attack from you by moving out of your Reach, you can use your Reaction to cast a Spell at the creature, rather than making an Opportunity Attack. The Spell must have a casting time of one Action and must target only that creature.

items.name: Somatic Components
items.entry: You can perform the Somatic Components of Spells even when you have Weapons or a Shield in one or both hands.

feat.name: Weapon Training
entries: You have practiced extensively with a variety of weapons, gaining the following benefits:

items.name: Weapon Proficiency
items.entry: You gain Martial Weapon Proficiency.

spell.name: Barkskin
entries: You touch one willing creature to protect it with regenerating bark. Until the Spell ends, the target's skin assumes a bark-like appearance, and at the start of each of the target's turns, the target gains a number of Temporary Hit Points equal to your Spellcasting Ability Modifier plus your Proficiency Bonus.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this Spell using a Spell Slot of 3rd level or higher, you can target one additional willing creature for each slot level above 2nd.

spell.name: Guidance

time.condition: which you take in response to you or an ally within 30 feet of you failing an {@variantrule Ability Check|XUA2022ExpertClasses}

entries: You channel magical insight to the creature who failed the {@variantrule Ability Check|XUA2022ExpertClasses}. That creature can roll a {@dice d4} and add the number rolled to the check, potentially turning it into a success.
Once a creature rolls the die for this Spell, that creature can't benefit from the Spell again until the creature finishes a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ExpertClasses}.

entries.name: Light
entries: When you take the Attack Action on your turn and attack with a Light weapon in one hand, you can make one extra attack as part of the same Action. That extra attack must be made with a different Light weapon in the other hand, and you don't add your Ability Modifier to the extra attack's damage. You can make this extra attack only once on each of your turns.

For example, if you take the Attack Action on your turn and have a Shortsword in one hand and a Dagger in the other—each of which has the Light property—you can make one attack with each weapon, but you don't add your Strength or Dexterity Modifier to the damage roll of the second weapon.

variantrule.name: Ability Check
entries: The Ability Check is one of three types of {@dice d20} Tests. The rules often call for an Ability Check, and the DM can also call for an Ability Check, determining which ability to use when a creature attempts something (other than an {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ExpertClasses} or a Saving Throw) that has a chance of meaningful failure. When the outcome is uncertain and narratively interesting, the dice determine the results.
The Ability Check has the following special rules.

entries.name: Skills
entries: When you make an Ability Check, the rules or the DM determines whether a Skill Proficiency is relevant to the check. If you have a relevant Skill Proficiency, you can add your Proficiency Bonus to the roll. For example, if a rule refers to a Strength Check ({@skill Acrobatics} or {@skill Athletics}), you can add your Proficiency Bonus to the check if you have {@skill Acrobatics} or {@skill Athletics} Proficiency.

entries.name: Action Required
entries: Making an Ability Check requires you to take an Action unless a rule says otherwise. Several of the named Actions—such as {@action Hide|XUA2022ExpertClasses} and {@action Influence|XUA2022ExpertClasses}—include Ability Checks.
The DM may override this requirement and allow a particular Ability Check to be made as part of a Bonus Action or as no Action at all.

entries.name: Difficulty Class
entries: The DM determines the Difficulty Class of an Ability Check and can override a DC specified in the rules. The Typical Difficulty Class table shows the most common DCs.
The default DC for a check is 15, and it is rarely worth calling for an Ability Check if the DC is as low as 5, unless the potential failure is narratively interesting.

variantrule.name: Arcane Spells
entries: An Arcane Spell draws on the ambient magic of the multiverse. Bards, Sorcerers, Warlocks, and Wizards harness this magic, as do Artificers. For a partial list of Arcane Spells, see the "{@variantrule Spell Lists|XUA2022ExpertClasses}" section elsewhere in this document.

variantrule.name: Armor Training
entries: Armor Training is the new name for Armor Proficiency. Any existing rule that involves Armor Proficiency now applies to Armor Training.

If you wear Light, Medium, or Heavy Armor and lack Armor Training with that type of Armor, you have Disadvantage on any {@dice d20} Test you make that involves Strength or Dexterity, and you can't cast Spells.
If you equip a Shield and lack Armor Training with Shields, you don't gain the Armor Class bonus of the Shield.

variantrule.name: Artisan's Tools
entries: Artisan's Tools are a category of tool with which a character can gain {@variantrule Tool Proficiency|XUA2022ExpertClasses}. For a list of Artisan's Tools, see the 2014 {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}, but ignore the prices there; those tools now cost 15 GP apiece.

variantrule.name: Attack Roll
entries: The Attack Roll is one of three types of {@dice d20} Tests. This Unearthed Arcana article uses the rules for attack rolls and critical hits found in the 2014 {@book Player's Handbook|PHB|9|Attack Rolls}.

variantrule.name: Blindsight
entries: If you have Blindsight, you can effectively see within a specific range without relying on physical sight. Within that range, you can effectively see anything that isn't behind Total Cover, even if you're Blinded or in Darkness. Moreover, you can effectively see a {@condition Hidden|XUA2022ExpertClasses} or an {@condition Invisible|XUA2022ExpertClasses} creature in that range.

variantrule.name: Climb Speed
entries: A Climb Speed can be used to move on a vertical surface without expending the extra movement normally associated with climbing. A Climb Speed can also be used in any situation in which your Speed is usable.
Some creatures have the Spider Climb trait, which allows their Climb Speed to work even on the underside of horizontal surfaces.

variantrule.name: Creature Type
entries: All creatures in D&D, including every player character, has a special tag in the rules that identifies the type of creature they are. Most player characters are of the Humanoid type.
Here's a list of the game's Creature Types in alphabetical order:

These types don't have rules themselves, but some rules in the game affect creatures of certain types in different ways. For example, the description of the {@spell Cure Wounds} Spell specifies the healing doesn't work on a Construct.

variantrule.name: D20 Tests
entries: The term {@dice d20} Test encompasses the three main {@dice d20} rolls of the game: {@variantrule Ability Check|XUA2022ExpertClasses}s, {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Attack Rolls}, and Saving Throws. If something in the game affects {@dice d20} Tests, it affects all three of these rolls.

Whenever a player character rolls a 1 for a {@dice d20} Test, that character gains {@variantrule Heroic Inspiration|XUA2022ExpertClasses}. The DM determines whether a {@dice d20} Test is warranted in any given circumstance

variantrule.name: Difficult Terrain
entries: If a space is Difficult Terrain, every foot of movement in that space costs 1 extra foot. For example, moving 5 feet through Difficult Terrain costs 10 feet of movement. Difficult Terrain isn't cumulative; either a space is Difficult Terrain or it isn't.
A space is Difficult Terrain for a creature if the space contains any of the following:

items: Furniture that is Small or larger
Liquid that's between shin- and waist-deep (any deeper and you need to Swim)
Narrow opening that is sized for a creature one
Pit or another gap of 2–5 feet

entries: The DM may determine that other things count as Difficult Terrain based on the examples here.

variantrule.name: Divine Spells
entries: A Divine Spell draws on the power of gods and the Outer Planes. Clerics and Paladins harness this magic. For a partial list of Divine Spells, see the "{@variantrule Spell Lists|XUA2022ExpertClasses}" section elsewhere in this document.

variantrule.name: Expertise
entries: Expertise is a special feature that enhances your use of a particular Skill Proficiency. If you gain Expertise, you gain it in one Skill in which you have Proficiency. You can never have Expertise in the same Skill Proficiency more than once.
When you make an {@variantrule Ability Check|XUA2022ExpertClasses} with a Skill Proficiency in which you have Expertise, your Proficiency Bonus is doubled for that check.

variantrule.name: Fly Speed
entries: A Fly Speed can be used to move through the air. While you have a Fly Speed, you can stay aloft until you land, fall, or die.
While flying, you fall if you are {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2022ExpertClasses} or Restrained. If you have the Hover trait, you can stay aloft even while Incapacitated or Restrained

variantrule.name: Gaming Set
entries: Gaming Sets are a category of tool with which a character can gain {@variantrule Tool Proficiency|XUA2022ExpertClasses}. For a list of Gaming Sets, see the 2014 {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}, but ignore the prices there; those sets now cost 1 GP apiece.

variantrule.name: Heroic Inspiration
entries: When you have Heroic Inspiration (also called Inspiration), you can expend it to give yourself Advantage on a {@dice d20} Test. You decide to do so immediately after rolling the {@dice d20}.
Gaining Heroic Inspiration

A player character gains Heroic Inspiration if the character rolls a 1 for a {@dice d20} Test. That 1 must be on the {@dice d20} used for the test's total, not on a {@dice d20} that was rerolled or discarded. This Heroic Inspiration represents a character's resolve to do better after fumbling an attempt.
The DM can also award Heroic Inspiration to a player character who's done something that is particularly heroic or in character.
Only One at a Time

You can never have more than one instance of Heroic Inspiration. If something gives you Heroic Inspiration and you already have it, you can give Heroic Inspiration to a player character in your group who lacks it.

variantrule.name: Long Rest
entries: A Long Rest is a period of extended downtime—at least 8 hours long—available to any creature. During a Long Rest, you sleep for at least 6 hours and perform no more than 2 hours of light activity, such as reading, talking, eating, or standing watch.
Benefits of the Rest
When you finish a Long Rest, you gain the following benefits:
Regain All HP. You regain all lost Hit Points.
Regain All HD. You regain all spent Hit Dice.
HP Max Restored. If your Hit Point Maximum was reduced, it returns to normal.

entries.name: Ability Scores Restored
entries: If any of your Ability Scores were reduced, they return to normal.
You can't benefit from more than one Long Rest in a 24-hour period, and you must have at least 1 Hit Point at the start of the rest to gain its benefits.
Interrupting the Rest

If a Long Rest is interrupted by combat or by 1 hour of walking, casting Spells, or similar activity, the rest confers no benefit and must be restarted; however, if the rest was at least 1 hour long before the interruption, you gain the benefits of a Short Rest.

variantrule.name: Move
entries: When you Move, you can go a distance equal to your Speed or less. For example, if you have a Speed of 30 feet, you can go up to 30 feet when you Move. {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XUA2022ExpertClasses} can slow you down.
Breaking Up Your Move

You can break up your Move, using some of its movement before and after any Action you take on the same turn. For example, if you have a Speed of 30 feet, you could go 10 feet, take an Action, and then go 20 feet.

entries.name: Moving Around Other Creatures
entries: During your Move, you can pass through the space of an ally, an {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2022ExpertClasses} creature, a Tiny creature, or a creature who is two Sizes larger or smaller than you.
Another creature's space is {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XUA2022ExpertClasses} for you, unless that creature is Tiny. You can't willingly end your Move in a space occupied by another creature.

entries.name: Climbing and Swimming
entries: You can use your Speed to climb or swim. Some creatures also have a {@variantrule Climb Speed|XUA2022ExpertClasses} or a {@variantrule Swim Speed|XUA2022ExpertClasses}.

If you use your Speed to climb or swim, each foot of movement costs 1 extra foot. For example, if you swim or climb 5 feet, you must spend 10 feet of movement to do so with your Speed. If you're swimming or climbing through {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XUA2022ExpertClasses}, that 5 feet of movement costs 15 feet!

entries.name: Special Speeds
entries: Some creatures have special speeds, such as a {@variantrule Climb Speed|XUA2022ExpertClasses}, a {@variantrule Fly Speed|XUA2022ExpertClasses}, or a {@variantrule Swim Speed|XUA2022ExpertClasses}. If you have more than one speed, you must choose which one to use each time you take your Move. For example, if you have a Speed and a {@variantrule Climb Speed|XUA2022ExpertClasses}, you can use one of those speeds when you Move, not both during the same Move.

If you take more than one Move on a turn and have more than one speed, each Move can use the same speed or a different one. For example, if you have both a Speed and a {@variantrule Fly Speed|XUA2022ExpertClasses} and you take the {@action Dash|XUA2022ExpertClasses} Action on your turn, you could use your Speed for the Move and your {@variantrule Fly Speed|XUA2022ExpertClasses} for the {@action Dash|XUA2022ExpertClasses} or vice versa.

entries.name: Speed of 0
entries: If an effect zeroes your Speed for a time, any special speed you have is also zeroed for the same duration. For example, if you have a Speed and a {@variantrule Climb Speed|XUA2022ExpertClasses}, both speeds are zeroed if you're subjected to the {@condition Grappled|XUA2022ExpertClasses} Condition.

variantrule.name: Musical Instrument
entries: Musical Instruments are a category of tool with which a character can gain {@variantrule Tool Proficiency|XUA2022ExpertClasses}. For a list of Musical Instruments, see the 2014 {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}, but ignore the prices there; those instruments now cost 20 GP apiece.

variantrule.name: Primal Spells
entries: A Primal Spell draws on the forces of nature and the Inner Planes. Druids and Rangers harness this magic. For a partial list of Primal Spells, see the "{@variantrule Spell Lists|XUA2022ExpertClasses}" section elsewhere in this document.

variantrule.name: Ritual Casting
entries: If you have a Spell prepared that has the Ritual tag, you can cast that Spell as a Ritual. A special feature is no longer required for Ritual casting. All the other rules on Rituals in the 2014 Player's Handbook still apply.

variantrule.name: Swim Speed
entries: A Swim Speed can be used to move through a liquid without expending the extra movement normally associated with swimming.

variantrule.name: Teleportation
entries: Teleportation is a special kind of magical transportation. If you teleport, you disappear and reappear elsewhere instantly, without moving through the intervening space. This transportation doesn't expend movement, unless a rule tells you otherwise, and teleportation never provokes Opportunity Attacks.

When you teleport, all the equipment you are wearing and carrying teleports with you. If you are touching another creature when you teleport, that creature doesn't teleport with you, unless the teleportation effect says otherwise.

If the destination space of your teleportation is occupied by another creature or blocked by a solid obstacle, you instead appear in the nearest unoccupied space of your choice. The description of a teleportation effect tells you if you must see the teleportation's destination.

variantrule.name: Tool Proficiency
entries: If you have Proficiency with a tool, you can add your Proficiency Bonus to any {@variantrule Ability Check|XUA2022ExpertClasses} you make that uses that tool. If you have Proficiency in the Skill that's also used with that check, you have Advantage on the check too. This means you can benefit from both Skill Proficiency and Tool Proficiency on the same {@variantrule Ability Check|XUA2022ExpertClasses}

variantrule.name: Tremorsense
entries: A creature with Tremorsense can pinpoint the location of creatures and moving objects within a specific range, provided that the creature with Tremorsense and anything it's detecting are both in contact with the same surface (such as the ground, a wall, or a ceiling) or the same liquid.
Tremorsense can't detect creatures or objects in the air, and Tremorsense doesn't count as a form of sight.

variantrule.name: Unarmed Strike
entries: An Unarmed Strike is a melee attack that involves you using your body to damage, grapple, or shove a target within your Reach.
Your bonus to hit with an Unarmed Strike equals your Strength modifier plus your Proficiency Bonus. On a hit, your Unarmed Strike causes one of the following effects of your choice:

entries.name: Damage
entries: The target takes Bludgeoning Damage equal to 1 + your Strength modifier.

entries.name: Grapple
entries: The target is {@condition Grappled|XUA2022ExpertClasses}, and the grapple's escape DC equals 8 + your Strength modifier + your Proficiency Bonus. This grapple is possible only if the target is no more than one Size larger than you and if you have a hand free to grab the target.

entries.name: Shove
entries: You either push the target 5 feet away or knock the target Prone. This shove is possible only if the target is no more than one Size larger than you.

condition.name: Exhausted
entries: While you are subjected to the Exhausted Condition (known in older books as Exhaustion), you experience the following effects:

items.name: Levels of Exhaustion
items.entry: This Condition is cumulative. Each time you receive it, you gain 1 level of {@condition exhaustion}. You die if your {@condition exhaustion} level exceeds 10.

items.name: d20 Rolls Affected
items.entry: When you make a {@dice d20} Test, you subtract your {@condition exhaustion} level from the {@dice d20} roll.

items.name: Spell Save DCs Affected
items.entry: Subtract your {@condition exhaustion} level from the Spell save DC of any Spell you cast.

items.name: Ending the Condition
items.entry: Finishing a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ExpertClasses} removes 1 of your levels of {@condition exhaustion}. When your {@condition exhaustion} level reaches 0, you are no longer Exhausted.

condition.name: Grappled
entries: While you are Grappled, you experience the following effects:

items.name: Speed 0
entries: Your Speed is 0 and can't change.

items.name: Attacks Affected
entries: You have Disadvantage on {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Attack Rolls} against any target other than the grappler.

items.name: Movable
entries: The grappler can drag or carry you, but the grappler suffers the {@condition Slowed|XUA2022ExpertClasses} Condition while moving, unless you are Tiny or two or more Sizes smaller than the grappler.

items.name: Escape
entries: While Grappled, you can make a Dexterity or Strength Saving Throw against the grapple's escape DC at the end of each of your turns, ending the Condition on yourself on a success. The Condition also ends if the grappler is {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2022ExpertClasses} or if something moves you outside the grapple's range without using your Speed.

condition.name: Hidden
entries: While you are Hidden, you experience the following effects:

items.name: Concealed
entries: You aren't affected by any effect that requires its target to be seen.

items.name: Surprise
entries: If you are Hidden when you roll Initiative, you have Advantage on the roll.

items.name: Attacks Affected
entries: {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Attack Rolls} against you have Disadvantage, and your {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Attack Rolls} have Advantage.

items.name: Ending the Condition
entries: The Condition ends on you immediately after any of the following occurrences: you make a sound louder than a whisper, an enemy finds you, you make an {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ExpertClasses}, you cast a Spell with a verbal component, or you aren't Heavily Obscured or behind any Cover.

condition.name: Incapacitated
entries: While you are Incapacitated, you experience the following effects:

items.name: Inactive
entries: Your Concentration is broken.

items.name: No Concentration
entries: Your Concentration is broken.

items.name: Speechless
entries: You can't speak.

items.name: Surprised
entries: If you are Incapacitated when you roll Initiative, you have Disadvantage on the roll.

condition.name: Invisible
entries: While you are Invisible, you experience the following effects:

items.name: Unseeable
entries: You can't be seen, so you aren't affected by any effect that requires its target to be seen. Any equipment you are wearing or carrying also can't be seen.

items.name: Surprise
entries: If you are Invisible when you roll initiative, you have Advantage on the roll. Attacks Affected. {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Attack Rolls} against you have Disadvantage, and your {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Attack Rolls} have Advantage.

condition.name: Slowed
entries: While you are Slowed, you experience the following effects:

items.name: Limited Movement
entries: You must spend 1 extra foot of movement for every foot you move using your Speed.

items.name: Attacks Affected
entries: {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ExpertClasses|Attack Rolls} against you have Advantage.

items.name: Dexterity Saves Affected
entries: You have Disadvantage on Dexterity Saving Throws.

action.name: Attack
entries: When you take the Attack Action, you can make one attack with a Weapon or an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XUA2022ExpertClasses}.

entries.name: Equipping Weapons
entries: You can equip or unequip one Weapon before or after any attack you make as part of this Action, even if the attack is with an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XUA2022ExpertClasses}.

entries.name: Moving Between Attacks
entries: If you {@variantrule Move|XUA2022ExpertClasses} on your turn, you can use some or all of that movement to move between the attacks of this Action if you have a feature, such as Extra Attack, that gives you more than one attack as part of the Attack Action.

action.name: Dash
entries: Taking the Dash Action allows you to make a bonus {@variantrule Move|XUA2022ExpertClasses} during the current turn

action.name: Help
entries: When you take the Help Action, you do one of the following:

items.name: Assist Ability Check
entries: Choose one of your Skill Proficiencies and one ally who can see or hear you. You give Advantage to the next {@variantrule Ability Check|XUA2022ExpertClasses} that ally makes with the chosen Skill. This benefit expires if the ally doesn't use it before the start of your next turn. To give this assistance, you must be near enough to the ally to assist verbally or physically when the ally makes the check. The DM has final say on whether your assistance is possible.

items.name: Assist Attack Roll
entries: You momentarily distract an enemy within 5 feet of you, granting Advantage to the next {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ExpertClasses} by one of your allies against that enemy. This benefit expires at the start of your next turn.

action.name: Hide
entries: With the Hide Action, you try to conceal yourself. To do so, you must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity Check ({@skill Stealth}) while you're Heavily Obscured or behind Three-Quarters Cover or Total Cover, and you must be out of any visible enemy's line of sight; if you can see a creature, you can discern whether it can see you.
On a successful check, you are {@condition Hidden|XUA2022ExpertClasses}. Make note of your check's total, which becomes the DC for a creature to find you with a Wisdom Check ({@skill Perception}).

action.name: Influence
entries: With the Influence Action, you can try to influence another creature to do something you request or demand. This Action can be used only on creatures controlled by the DM, and it isn't mind control; it can't force a creature to do something that is counter to the creature's alignment or that is otherwise repugnant to the creature.
This Action has three main parts: Attitude, interaction, and a Charisma Check.

entries.name: Attitude
entries: A creature's Attitude determines how a character can influence that creature. Each DM-controlled creature has one of the following Attitudes toward the player characters:

items.name: Indifferent
entries: This is the default Attitude for DMcontrolled creatures. An Indifferent creature might help or hinder the party, depending on what the creature sees as most beneficial. A creature's indifference doesn't necessarily make it standoffish or disinterested. Indifferent creatures might be polite and genial, surly and irritable, or anything in between. A successful Charisma Check is often necessary when the adventurers try to persuade an Indifferent creature to do something.

items.name: Friendly
entries: A Friendly creature wants to help the adventurers and wishes for them to succeed. For tasks or actions that require no particular risk, effort, or cost, Friendly creatures often help happily. If an element of personal risk is involved, a successful Charisma Check might be required to convince a Friendly creature to take that risk.

items.name: Hostile
entries: A Hostile creature opposes the adventurers and their goals but doesn't necessarily attack them on sight. The adventurers need to succeed on one or more challenging Charisma Checks to convince a Hostile creature to do anything on the party's behalf; however, the DM might determine that the Hostile creature is so ill-disposed toward the characters that no Charisma Check can sway it, in which case the first check fails automatically and no further Influence attempts can be made on the creature unless its Attitude shifts.

entries.name: Interaction
entries: When you take the Influence Action, either roleplay how your character interacts with the creature or describe your character's behavior—focusing on your character's request or demand. If the interaction is especially suited to the creature's desires and outlook, the DM might grant Advantage to your subsequent check or might temporarily shift a Hostile creature to Indifferent or an Indifferent creature to Friendly.

Similarly, if the interaction is particularly irksome to the creature, the DM might impose Disadvantage on your subsequent check or might temporarily shift a Friendly creature to Indifferent or an Indifferent creature to Hostile.

entries.name: Ability Check
entries: To determine whether your request or demand is successful, you make a Charisma Check ({@skill Animal Handling}, {@skill Deception}, {@skill Intimidation}, or {@skill Persuasion}); the applicable Skill depends on the interaction, with {@skill Animal Handling} being reserved for Beasts and Monstrosities. Also, each request or demand requires a different check.
The creature's Attitude determines the DC required to achieve a specific response, as shown in the Influence Responses table.

tables.caption: Influence Responses
rows: The creature does as asked, as long as no risks or sacrifices are involved.
The creature accepts a minor risk or sacrifice to do as asked.
The creature accepts a minor risk or sacrifice to do as asked.
The creature accepts a significant risk or sacrifice to do as asked.
The creature offers no help but does no harm.
The creature does as asked, as long as no risks or sacrifices are involved.

action.name: Jump
entries: With the Jump Action, you attempt to leap more than 5 feet (a jump of 5 feet or less is treated as {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XUA2022ExpertClasses}). When you take this Action, your Speed must be greater than 0, and you must make a {@dc 10} Strength Check ({@skill Acrobatics} or {@skill Athletics}). If you don't {@variantrule Move|XUA2022ExpertClasses} at least 10 feet immediately before this Action, you have Disadvantage on the check.
On a failed check, you leap 5 feet horizontally or vertically.

On a successful check, the check's total determines the distance in feet that you can clear horizontally, or half that total if you're jumping vertically (round down). This jump doesn't expend your movement, but the distance you clear can't exceed your Speed.

action.name: Magic
entries: When you take the Magic Action, you cast a Spell that has a casting time of an Action, or you use a Magic Item that requires an Action to be activated.

If you cast a Spell that has a casting time of 1 minute or longer, you must take the Magic Action on each turn of that casting, and you must maintain Concentration while you do so. If your Concentration is broken, the Spell fails, but you don't expend a Spell Slot.

action.name: Search
entries: When you take the Search Action, you make a Wisdom Check to discern something that isn't obvious. The Search table suggests which Skills are applicable when you take this Action, depending on what you're trying to detect.

action.name: Study
entries: When you take the Study Action, you make an Intelligence Check to study your memory, a book, a creature, a clue, an object, or another source of knowledge and call to mind an important piece of information about it.
The Areas of Knowledge table suggests which Skills are applicable when you take this Action, depending on the area of knowledge the Intelligence Check is about.

entries.caption: Areas of Knowledge
rows: Spells, magic items, eldritch symbols, magical traditions, planes of existence, and certain creatures (Aberrations, Constructs, Elementals, Fey, and Monstrosities)
Historic events and people, ancient civilizations, wars, and certain creatures (Giants and Humanoids)
Terrain, flora, weather, and certain creatures (Beasts, Dragons, Oozes, and Plants)
Deities, religious hierarchies and rites, holy symbols, cults, and certain creatures (Celestials, Fiends, and Undead)
